body: Seriously, every subreddit holds applications but doesn't accept all of them because, since they've never moderated other large subs, they're either "untrustworthy" or "can't handle the job". It's kinda hard to moderate other large subs when the same thing applies and it's a catch-22. The only ones that ever get accepted as new mods are the ones that know somebody on the current mod team, everyone else is shut out. This is particularly bad with the main moderator cabal, DefaultMods, because it enjoys tons of special privileges and is closely tied to the admins, and 99.999999% of subreddits over 1k subscribers are controlled by them, at least in part.

It's kinda hard to moderate other large subs when the same thing applies and it's a catch-22. The only ones that ever get accepted as new mods are the ones that know somebody on the current mod team, everyone else is shut out. This is particularly bad with the main moderator cabal, DefaultMods, because it enjoys tons of special privileges and is closely tied to the admins, and 99.999999% of subreddits over 1k subscribers are controlled by them, at least in part.
title: Nepotism is the only way to get invited to moderate subreddits

author.bio:
Ruqqus cofounder and lead backend developer.

https://github.com/captainmeta4
author.bio_html:
Ruqqus cofounder and lead backend developer.

https://github.com/captainmeta4

body:
I've done mod application vetting, including multiple large subs. Typically what we were looking for is:

* Post history of good quality content with little to no inflammatory or flaming comments. Looking to make sure the person is level headed and not an asshole. Most applications get tossed in fifteen seconds or less because a quick glance at the profile reveals that they have no business being a moderator. 
* A good amount of participation in the subreddit
* Experience moderating anything else is helpful but not required
* Experience using tools like automod, praw, or toolbox is helpful but not required

I got into moderating just by being helpful and filling out subreddit wikis with useful info. From there I was able to social network my way into bigger subs with more opportunities and responsibilities. 

It's not maliciously closed or anything, but it's also not noob friendly
body_html:
I've done mod application vetting, including multiple large subs. Typically what we were looking for is:

  • Post history of good quality content with little to no inflammatory or flaming comments. Looking to make sure the person is level headed and not an asshole. Most applications get tossed in fifteen seconds or less because a quick glance at the profile reveals that they have no business being a moderator.
  • A good amount of participation in the subreddit
  • Experience moderating anything else is helpful but not required
  • Experience using tools like automod, praw, or toolbox is helpful but not required

I got into moderating just by being helpful and filling out subreddit wikis with useful info. From there I was able to social network my way into bigger subs with more opportunities and responsibilities.

It's not maliciously closed or anything, but it's also not noob friendly
